fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A preadditive category is a category enriched in abelian groups with their tensor product. Explicitly, this means it is a category such that each hom-set is an abelian group and composition is bilinear.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Categories and sheaves
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{riehl-2017, title = {Categories and Sheaves}, author = {Kashiwara, Masaki and Schapira, Pierre}, isbn = {978-3-540-27950-1}, publisher = {Springer Berlin}, year = {2005}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Categories and sheaves, which emerged in the middle of the last century as an enrichment for the concepts of sets and functions, appear almost everywhere in mathematics nowadays.

This book covers categories, homological algebra and sheaves in a systematic and exhaustive manner starting from scratch, and continues with full proofs to an exposition of the most recent results in the literature, and sometimes beyond.

The authors present the general theory of categories and functors, emphasising inductive and projective limits, tensor categories, representable functors, ind-objects and localization. Then they study homological algebra including additive, abelian, triangulated categories and also unbounded derived categories using transfinite induction and accessible objects. Finally, sheaf theory as well as twisted sheaves and stacks appear in the framework of Grothendieck topologies.
An additive category is a preadditive category with finite direct sums. (In particular, it has nullary direct sums, hence a zero object.)
An additive functor is an enriched functor between preadditive categories. Explicitly, this means it is a functor which acts on hom-sets by homomorphisms.

Since \mathbb {Z} is the initial ring, there is a unique ring homomorphism from \mathbb {Z} to \operatorname {End}(A) for any abelian group A. This defines an isomorphism of categories Ab \cong \mathbb {Z}Mod.

fr:title.text: Closed symmetric monoidal structure on modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closed symmetric monoidal structure on modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category of R-modules is closed symmetric monoidal, with the tensor product and internal hom.

Notice that this is exactly the universal property of the tensor product: a homomorphism M\otimes N\to O is the same as a bilinear map M\times N\to O, which by definition is the same as a module homomorphism M\to [N, O].

A bilinear map of R-modules from M and N to O is a set-function M\times N\xrightarrow {f} O from the cartesian product such that it is a homomorphism in each argument separately, i.e. for each m\in M and each n\in N, f(m, -) and f(-, n) are module homomorphisms. Explicitly, this means that f(m_1 + m_2, n) = f(m_1, n) + f(m_2, n), f(m, n_1 + n_2) = f(m, n_1) + f(m, n_2),\quad \text {and} f(rm, n) = rf(m, n) = f(m, rn).
Let \mathcal {V} be a monoidal category. A \mathcal {V}-category C, also called a category enriched in \mathcal {V}, consists of:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x, y\in C, an object C(x, y) of \mathcal {V}, called the hom-object;
for every triple of objects x, y, z\in C, a morphism C(y, z)\otimes C(x, y)\xrightarrow {\circ _{x,y,z}} C(x, z), called composition;
for evey object x\in C, a global element I\xrightarrow {1_x} C, called the identity.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must make the following associativity and unitality diagrams commute:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzcd} ( C(z, w)\otimes C(y,z))\otimes C(x, y) & & C(z, w)\otimes ( C(y,z)\otimes C(x, y)) \\ C(y, w)\otimes C(x, y) & C(x, y) & C(z, w)\otimes ( C(x, z)) \\ \arrow ["\alpha _{ C(z, w), C(y,z), C(x, y)}", from=1-1, to=1-3] \arrow ["\circ _{y, z, w}\otimes 1_{ C(x, y)}", from=1-1, to=2-1, swap] \arrow ["1_{ C(z, w)}\otimes \circ _{x, y, z}", from=1-3, to=2-3] \arrow ["\circ _{x, y, w}", from=2-1, to=2-2, swap] \arrow ["\circ _{x, z, w}", from=2-3, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An abelian group is a commutative group. Its operation is generally written additively, a + b.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
